title: Allow reporters to approve MRs if they are explicitly listed in the approval rules
description:
### Problem to solve

This issue is one is an iteration toward supporting the greater Enterprise's workflows to manage release approvals via MRs. When an operator is “allowed to deploy” to production, they need developer access and the ability to push/merge into the branch (if it's protected) in order to deploy into protected environments. This permits operators to commit code, causing auditing concerns.

A similar issue exists when a non-code-contributing Approver for merge requests is required. They must be developers to approve Merge Requests.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### Further details

* We will need to add a configuration option for groups to select maintainers cannot deploy, and only this deployer role can deploy.

### User experience goal

Users that have no access to modify the code (Reporters) ought to still be able to Approve MRs and Deploy to Protected Environments when they are designated as approvers or deployers

**Scenario**:

Developers (with developer access) to a project ought to be allowed to develop, push/merge into protected branches but NOT deploy to production. This is accomplished by pairing Protected Branches and Protected Environments with an externalized CI YAML.

Managers or Operators (with reporter access) to a project sometimes need to be required approvers of an MR before a merge to a protected branch commences. These managers/operators ought not be allowed to push/merge any code to any branches but. The only users that are able to "Approve" a Merge Request are users that can also push/merge code.  This prevents the MR Approvers from having segregation of duties.

### Proposal 
Spawned from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201898

The idea is to use the reporters role as "operators".

Allow reporter roles to approve MRs if they are explicitly listed in the approval rules.

epic.title: Deployer Role without access to code

title: Allow reporters to run jobs that deploy to an environments if they are explicitly listed
description:
### Problem to solve

**Users that have no access to modify the code (Reporters) ought to still be able to Approve MRs and Deploy to Protected Environments when they are designated as approvers or deployers**

When an operator is “allowed to deploy” to production, they need developer access and the ability to push/merge into the branch (if it's protected) in order to deploy into protected environments. This permits operators to commit code, causing auditing concerns.

A similar issue exists when a non-code-contributing Approver for merge requests is required. They must be developers to approve Merge Requests.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### Further details

* We will need to add a configuration option for groups to select maintainers cannot deploy, and only this deployer role can deploy.

* We want to let reporters run jobs but only if it’s job that has environment and they are allowed to deploy environments

This feature will work like this from the user's perspective:

1. A group is created with *Reporter* access, eg: *deployers*
1. The user is added to the *deployers* group as a *Reporter*

![Screenshot_2020-08-05_at_11.59.27](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/1977e9734412364141176a81f10a18c7/Screenshot_2020-08-05_at_11.59.27.png)

1. The *deployers* group is added to the project with *Reporter* access

![Screenshot_2020-08-05_at_11.57.23](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/759c7ca05db77b38aa9e093b3cef35ca/Screenshot_2020-08-05_at_11.57.23.png)

1. A Protected Environment is added against *production* with the group *deployers* having access

![Screenshot_2020-08-05_at_11.58.28](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/fb0125281584a7975705ab8ab2feb3d0/Screenshot_2020-08-05_at_11.58.28.png)

### Proposal
Spawned from: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201898

The idea is to use reporters as "operators".

> I would suggest the following logic:
> 
> 1. If the environment isn't protected, only developers can deploy.
> 1. If environment is protected, then all users/groups directly listed in the protected environment can deploy if they have at least reporter permissions to the project.


### Permissions and Security

The proposed solution does introduce an inconsistency given that it's an outlier that "allowed to deploy" users now have an elevated level of access specific to deployments. However, without it, I do not see a way to provide true segregation of duties.

The permissions are paired within the [Core Policies](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/app/policies/ci) and the [EE Policies](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/ee/app/policies/ee/ci).

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Premium"

title: Package Registry: Adjust the max width for non-fluid screens to be 990
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

The package registry list view shows users a list of all the packages contained inside of a registry through a list view. 

Currently, the UI width has a max of 1248px. Given the content in the page, a 1248px width is too wide and can hinder users to draw connections on a single line item on either side of the line.

| Current width |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_12.59.38](/uploads/dce5f12a10af4fa9f365f88169ea9f3c/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_12.59.38.png)|

### Intended users


* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### User experience goal

Help users consume the data on the Package Registry list view by shortening the width of the page for users who have not opted for the "fluid layout" mode. This should help users connect data we display on the left and right side of a line item.


### Proposal

Set the width of the Package Registry UI to be 990px by default (unless a user has selected the fluid-layout mode).

| Package List at 990px wide |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_13.02.46](/uploads/98c89117b9467f3a3aa83e07dd24aca5/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_13.02.46.png) |

### Further details

The reason the width of the Package Registry UI may be a result of the two-column layout in the Package Detail View

| Package Detail View |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_13.05.20](/uploads/9bcadd7c1809dc51e1ea607d50058363/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_13.05.20.png)|

If this is the case, we should not adjust the width of the Package Registry List view until the Package Detail View can also come down to the 990px goal width.

We currently have a design issue dedicated to putting the package details into a single column: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225337.

this issue may be blocked until we complete the single column layout change because having the UI width change between the list and detail view could be jarring for users.

@nmezzopera could you confirm this? 

### Permissions and Security

n/a

### Documentation

Its possible screenshots of the UI will need to be updated in the documentation, but that may not be necessary for "just" changing the width.

### Availability & Testing

n/a

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

The package registry list and detail views both render at 990px wide for users who have not selected the "fluid UI" preference.

### What is the type of buyer?

n/a

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

n/a

title: VSA - Add info icons to explain lead time / cycle time calculations
description:
### Problem

It isn't obvious how the lead time and cycle time numbers are calculated. Rather than having to hunt in the docs, users should be able to see how calculations are performed from the UI.

### Proposal

* Add info bubbles with mouse-overs that tell users how the calculations are performed.

|  |  |
| ------ | ------ |
| Info bubbles help users understand the stage and medium columns. Use these to explain the calculations for lead time and cycle time. | ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_1.48.00_AM](/uploads/c7927647865786c29bbb65c2855e8251/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_1.48.00_AM.png) | 
 
From the [docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/value_stream_analytics.html#how-time-metrics-are-measured):
```
Lead time: median time from issue created to issue closed. 
Cycle time: median time from first commit to issue closed.'
```

title: VSA Project Selection - Projects Can Disappear
description:
### Problem

In this walk-through [video](https://youtu.be/7qvUQfPGr-E?t=1718), the user struggles to find the gitlab project in the drop-down. I have experienced a similar issue with the project selection when creating a new issue from an epic and I suspect these may share a root cause. 

In my experience of the problem, it appears that the drop-down's sort order would change randomly and that it was also not properly paginated so that, if I was unlucky, the project I intended to select (almost always GitLab) would never come up. 

| VSA Drop-down | Create Issue from Epic Project Drop-down |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_1.08.42_AM](/uploads/c73b6e6c22704e0dd173908b03325cf2/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_1.08.42_AM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_1.30.35_AM](/uploads/af0babbe83dd6492803b594762e2332d/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_1.30.35_AM.png) |

### Further details

Project selection from the drop-down is a recurring problem [in Analytics features](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32330) and [elsewhere in gitlab](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/212718).

One great idea to solve this problem is by scoring search results as described in #221043.

### Proposal

Project selection in group-level VSA should use the search result scoring introduced under https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221043.

title: Dashboards MVC Render Charts in Two Column Layout [FE]
description:
Part of &3711

### Problem

Render charts on the dashboard page in a two-column layout. 

### Proposal

* Render the charts in a [layout two charts wide](#layout), scrolling to an undefined number of charts.
* The API defined in [dashboards route and controller setup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225429) provides a list of the Report Pages charts to render and are rendered in the order provided, left to right and then on to the next row.
* Retrieve and render chart data in the same manner as Report Pages.
* Clicking on the chart should link the user to the Report Page from whence it came.

### Visual

| Dashboard  | Report Page | 
| ------     | ------      |
| ![group-activity-dashboard-01](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/6db69088894e13f1a5cd0af1009992e7/group-activity-dashboard-01.png) | ![Group_recent_activity__issues_opened_mvc](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/1a95d33e1646ba35b807baed29c4886f/Group_recent_activity__issues_opened_mvc.png) |
| The dashboard page displays two charts side by side. The selection of charts is determined by a YAML file which references charts on report pages. | One can click on the chart in the dashboard to drill-down to the corresponding report page. When the Report Page has a [data table](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220295) this will seem less odd. |

### Layout 

|   |   |
| ------ | ------ |
| Chart 1 | Chart 2 |
| Chart 3 | Chart 4 |

title: Automate the deletion of the old Index after a reindex has completed
description:
### Overview
Currently every time we do a reindex we have to manually delete the old index. 
usually we wait for confirmation that the reindex is completed and of good quality before deleting the old index. 
If something was wrong coping back the old index may prove to be the most practical solution. 

### Proposal
Because deleting the old index after the reindexing is a manual task that is required often we should Automate this to simplify this task. 
Because some self-managed users might not want to delete the old index this should include a change to the UI where we allow the user to cancel. 
This should also be accompanied with a Message that explains when the old index will be deleted. 

### Things to consider
- What test confirms the new index is healthy prior to deletion? 
- Should the cancel button just be a disable? 
  - Disable/Enable automatic deletion of old index. 
  - Should the messaging also confirm the new index is working? 
- What default should we use for time till deletion? 2 weeks from confirmation the new index is healthy?


### Discussion leading to this proposal

The following discussion from !34069 should be addressed:

- [ ] @DylanGriffith started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34069#note_369667231):  (+4 comments)

    > Perhaps we should not delete the index for now. I've not been deleting until later in case something goes wrong when doing the reindexing

Terri Chu
Terri Chu @terrichu · 1 day ago
Developer

When doing reindexing manually in the past, I've always left the previous index in place until I was happy with the new one. I was thinking about how this could be automated. Maybe the route that project deletions are done (scheduled in the future with some messaging to the user)? It seems like it could be a new issue to figure it out anyhow. WDYT?

Dmitry Gruzd
Dmitry Gruzd @dgruzd · 1 day ago
Developer

@terrichu this is a great idea, thanks! We might display a warning message that the index will be deleted after N days with a button to cancel. Let's create an issue for that 👍

title: Define YAML for analytics dashboards (BE)
description:
Part of &3711

### Problem to Solve

Load configuration for a dashboard via a YAML file.

### Proposal

* User created dashboards are out-of-scope. See &3737.
* Eventually we may have more sophisticated layouts, but for now we will just send the page and ordered list of charts.
* Assign the Group Recent Activity Dashboard a slug of `group_recent_activity`.
* The YAML snippet below specifies not only the chart slug, but also indicates that it is the chart which should be displayed. In the future, Report Pages may define other kinds of renderings such as a data table or or summary card with a single numeral and specifying `chart` allows us to pick the right bit to render.

## Sample YAML

(Just for context.)

```yaml
group_recent_activity:
  title: Recent Activity Dashboard
  layout: two_column_template
  metric_widgets:
    - report_page: recent_merge_requests_by_group
      display: chart
    - report_page: recent_issues_by_group
      display: chart
```

This is somewhat analogous to what we did at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221077.

epic.title: Dashboards MVC

title: [Analytics] Dashboards route and controller setup (BE)
description:
Part of &3711

### Problem to Solve
 
Create a route/page for serving up dashboards in Analytics.

### Proposal 

* Proposed route: `https://gitlab.com/-/analytics/dashboards/:dashboard_slug`
* The slug is defined in a YAML file that represents default system configuration.
* User created dashboards are out-of-scope. See &3737.
   * (When we do get to user created dashboards we may want want the route for those under a group that owns the dashboard.)
* An end-point will tell page the what charts to render based on the YAML definition covered in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225431.
* Eventually we may have more sophisticated layouts, but for now we will just send the page and ordered list of charts.
* Users should be able to click on a dashboard chart to navigate to down to report page from whence it came, so passing along the Report Page URL (or data elements required to construct it) will be important to the FE.

### Sample YAML

(Just for context.)

```yaml
group_recent_activity:
  title: Recent Activity Dashboard
  layout: two_column_template
  metric_widgets:
    - report_page: recent_merge_requests_by_group
      display: chart
    - report_page: recent_issues_by_group
      display: chart
```

title: Add files from the PyPI Repository to the storage counter
description:
### Problem to solve

System Administrators need the ability to understand how storage is being used across projects, groups at the instance level. Currently, they can see how much space the Package Registry uses. However PyPI packages are not included in this dashboard.

### Intended users

* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### Further details
![Screen_Shot_2020-07-13_at_2.27.00_PM](/uploads/91a726b8b24a8cf264a415932f8dd511/Screen_Shot_2020-07-13_at_2.27.00_PM.png)

### Proposal

Ensure that when PyPI packages are uploaded or deleted, that the Group-level `Usage quotas` storage counter is accurate and up-to-date.

### Permissions
- Only Group-level Admin can see the Usage quotas page

### Documentation
* Add a section to the [Package Registry Admin docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/packages/index.html) that demonstrates how to check how much storage the Package Registry is using for a given project(s).

### Availability & Testing

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

* Success looks like Admin can trust that we are accurately counting storage usage for PyPI packages

title: DAST Site profile - add support for Authentication, Request headers & Excluded Urls - Backend
description:
- Parent issue: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3766
- ~frontend counterpart: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225378

## Summary

This is the second ~backend iteration for building the **DAST site profile** form MVC. At this point, we should have a basic form already done, and we're going to add the **Authentication** section, as well as the **Request headers** field.

## Flow

- `user` creates a new `dast_site_profile`
  - secret variables are base64 encoded and stored in associated table called `dast_site_profile_secret_variables`
  - non-secret variables stored on `dast_site_profile`

<hr/>

- `user` updates `dast_site_profile`:
  - `DastSiteProfiles::CreateService` updates:
    - `dast_site_profile`
    - corresponding `dast_site_profile_secret_variables`

<hr/>

- `user` deletes `dast_site_profile`:
  - `DastSiteProfiles::CreateService` deletes:
    - `dast_site_profile`
    - corresponding `dast_site_profile_secret_variables`

<hr/>

- `user` runs a new on-demand dast scan
  - `Contexable` fetches associated `dast_site_profile_secret_variables`

<hr/>

- `dast` runs new scan:
  - decodes `base64` encoded fields

## Implementation Plan

1. [ ] define the explicit relationship between CI pipeline model and DAST profile model.
1. [ ] allow users to register auth secrets in DAST site profile.
1. [ ] inject the auth secrets into job variables.

## Contract

```diff
--- proposal_iteration1.graphl
+++ proposal_iteration2.graphl
@@ -2,12 +2,26 @@ mutation dastSiteProfileCreate(
   $fullPath: ID!
   $profileName: String!
   $targetUrl: String
+  $authEnabled: Boolean!
+  $authUsername: String
+  $authUrl: String
+  $authUsernameField: String
+  $authPasswordField: String
+  $authPassword: String
+  $excludedUrls: String
+  $requestHeaders: String
 ) {
   dastSiteProfileCreate(
     input: {
       fullPath: $fullPath
       profileName: $profileName
       targetUrl: $targetUrl
+      auth: {
+       enabled: $authEnabled
+        url: $authUrl
+        usernameField: $authUsernameField
+        passwordField: $authPasswordField
+        username: $authUsername
+        password: $authPassword
+      }
+      excludedUrls: $excludedUrls
+      requestHeaders: $requestHeaders
     }
   ) {
     id
```

epic.title: DAST Site profile - add remaining options

title: VSA says not enough data when there is too much data
description:
### Problem to Solve

In this walk-through [video](https://youtu.be/7qvUQfPGr-E?t=1718) several VSA stages are shown as "not enough data", but it seems the problem is too much data.

### Further details

[Productivity Analytics has the same behavior](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217858), probably for the same reason - query timeout.

### Proposal

When there is a query timeout on the backend, this error message is displayed on the frontend: "There is too much data to calculate. Please change your selection."

title: Re-add the feature of swapping branches on Compare view
description:
### Summary

This button was removed in this issue > https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/14615#note_493733369 

Let's reintroduce this button per this updated mock. The functionality was unclear in the original as noted in the above issue comment. So let's figure out what's the expected behaviour of this button 👍

![image](/uploads/c04ec1f7e05a9504578831cf691bfb49/image.png)

---

<details>
<summary>Old description</summary>

# Swapping branches on comparison page doesn't work as expected

### Summary

When starting the branch comparison process, after selecting a branch, then clicking the swap button, the page reloads and resets the source and target branches to `master`. 

![compare-issue](/uploads/bbc6eadc7b4c30dd72179cdc510ca7be/compare-issue.mov)

### What's expected

I expect the swap icon to swap the source and target branch, regardless of whether or not you're actively comparing branches.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enter the comparison page: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/compare?from=master&to=master
2. Select a branch other than `master` in the `source` dropdown
3. Click `Swap revision` icon to swap the source and target branches.

</details>

title: Geo: Document how to handle a repmgr failover
description:
I believe that replication will break when the primary is using an HA PostgreSQL cluster using `repmgr` and a PG failover happens to another DB node. We should document this and make a recommendation as to mitigation steps.

### Situation

1. Initial setup
```mermaid
 graph TD
   subgraph Geo deployment
   subgraph Primary[Primary site, main rpmgr cluster]
    DB_1[DB main leader] --> DB_2[DB follower]
    DB_1[DB main leader] --> DB_3[DB follower]
  end
  subgraph Secondary[Secondary site]
    DB_1[DB main leader] --> DB_4["DB Geo standby"]
   end
   end
```
2. PG failover on primary site

A new node is promoted via repmgr; geo replication breaks and manual intervention is needed
```mermaid
 graph TD
   subgraph Geo deployment
   subgraph Primary[Primary site, main rpmgr cluster]
    DB_2[DB new leader]
    DB_2[DB new leader] --> DB_3[DB follower]
  end
  subgraph Secondary[Secondary site]
    DB_4["DB Geo standby"]
   end
   end
```

### Proposal

1. Document the situation
1. Add a section to troubleshooting guide to recommend mitigation steps

epic.title: Geo: Secondary nodes should support PostgreSQL clusters

title: Make Deployments a top level navigation element
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

With our progressive delivery functionality becoming more and more mature we notice a few patterns:
- Feature Flags and future experiments such as A/B testing require a dedicated place to discuss intent, lifespan, and results (research insight will be added later)
- The amount of people involved in the delivery of a feature is expanding beyond just engineering.
- Delivery is the most critical part of feature development as it will make the feature user facing/noticeable on production.
- A/B testing is seen as separate from FF (research insight will be added later)

Currently, we are looking for a place to put our experiments aside from feature flags. It will probably not make sense to have it hidden inside of one of the only-engineering focused menus.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)

-->

>>>

title: Report changelog version in Go-based analyzers
description:
### Problem to solve

The GitLab Container Scanning tool currently outputs the latest version in the changelog when running a container scan:

```
[INFO] [klar] [2020-06-30T18:20:17+10:00] ▶ GitLab klar analyzer v2.4.7
```

By outputting the information during a scan, it makes it much easier to determine the exact version of the analyzer, which is extremely useful for bug reports.

The purpose of this issue is to add the latest changelog version to the [app.Version](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/733d29da8ec70823a4ec81d623218f58a60b6bd9/main.go#L23) field, and output this value for all Go-based analyzers.

See [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28566#note_320149905) for more details

### Additional Details

The following provides some supporting evidence to illustrate why this change would be useful

#### Example 1

While investigating the [following issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/208085#note_374060843), the end-user provided the output log from the failing container scanning job, which included the semantic version of the analyzer `v2.4.8`, but _did not_ include the SHA of the docker image of the analyzer, which would have required additional back and forth to request that this information be included in the output log.

#### Example 2

In [the following `tests/js-yarn` job](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/js-yarn/-/jobs/620623531), it's not possible to know exactly which version of the underlying [`retire.js` analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js) is used because the image SHA of the `retire.js` analyzer is not output:

```
Unable to find image 'registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning:2' locally
2: Pulling from gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning
ce82f9486b57: Pulling fs layer
ce82f9486b57: Verifying Checksum
ce82f9486b57: Download complete
ce82f9486b57: Pull complete
Digest: sha256:29914ecaaa6a0387b7d0a679a6f5ee1cbe28211c3279cbdfaef6e1ace4b41516
Status: Downloaded newer image for registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning:2
2020/07/02 06:27:27 Copy project directory to containers
2020/07/02 06:27:27 [tmp] No detection plugin named
2020/07/02 06:27:27 [tmp] Downloading analyzer...
..........................................................2020/07/02 06:27:37 [tmp] Starting analyzer...
...
[INFO] [retire.js] [2020-07-02T06:27:41Z] ▶ Detecting project
[INFO] [retire.js] [2020-07-02T06:27:41Z] ▶ Found project in /tmp/app
[INFO] [retire.js] [2020-07-02T06:27:41Z] ▶ Running analyzer
```

However, if we insert the `app.Version` value and output it in the [`retire.js` analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js), then we can see exactly what version is being used, as shown in the [following `tests/js-yarn` log](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/js-yarn/-/jobs/620663535):

```
Unable to find image 'registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning:2' locally
2: Pulling from gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning
ce82f9486b57: Pulling fs layer
ce82f9486b57: Verifying Checksum
ce82f9486b57: Download complete
ce82f9486b57: Pull complete
Digest: sha256:29914ecaaa6a0387b7d0a679a6f5ee1cbe28211c3279cbdfaef6e1ace4b41516
Status: Downloaded newer image for registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning:2
2020/07/02 07:04:41 Copy project directory to containers
2020/07/02 07:04:41 [tmp] No detection plugin named
2020/07/02 07:04:41 [tmp] Downloading analyzer...
............................................................
2020/07/02 07:04:52 [tmp] Starting analyzer...
[INFO] [Retire.js] [2020-07-02T07:04:55Z] ▶ GitLab Retire.js analyzer v2.6.1
[INFO] [Retire.js] [2020-07-02T07:04:55Z] ▶ Detecting project
[INFO] [Retire.js] [2020-07-02T07:04:55Z] ▶ Found project in /tmp/app
[INFO] [Retire.js] [2020-07-02T07:04:55Z] ▶ Running analyzer
```

As shown above, we can easily determine the exact version of the `retire.js` analyzer:

```
[INFO] [Retire.js] [2020-07-02T07:04:55Z] ▶ GitLab Retire.js analyzer v2.6.1
```

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)

### User experience goal

Version number will be output for all analyzers to make it more obvious which version a customer is using when submitting a bug report.

### Proposal

1. [x] Update the [build stage of analyzer.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/07c90cb890328b5df68cf8ef1c684ffb2fb1fd42/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L58-67) to extract the latest version from the `CHANGELOG.md` file and pass it as an argument to the `ldflags` parameter when building the `analyzer` binary:

   ```sh
    - CHANGELOG_VERSION=$(grep -m 1 '^## v.*$' "CHANGELOG.md" | sed 's/## v//')
    - PATH_TO_MODULE=`go list -m`
    - go build -ldflags="-X '$PATH_TO_MODULE/metadata.AnalyzerVersion=$CHANGELOG_VERSION'" -o ${CI_PROJECT_DIR}/analyzer
   ```

   https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/165

1. [x] Add the above logic to the `Dockerfile` for each analyzer that uses a separate binary build stage

      - [x] [klar](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/blob/d281fc9/Dockerfile#L29-34)
         - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/merge_requests/64
      - [x] [spotbugs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/blob/ff2b2d3/Dockerfile#L5-5)
         - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs/-/merge_requests/73
      - [x] [kubesec](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec/blob/20d417c/Dockerfile#L5-5)
         - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec/-/merge_requests/36
      - [x] [secrets](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/blob/ea88751/Dockerfile#L6-6)
         - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/merge_requests/78
      - [x] [bandit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/blob/fa70be0/Dockerfile#L5-5)
         - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/merge_requests/53/
      - [x] [pmd-apex](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex/blob/6c202fa/Dockerfile#L5-5)

title: ServiceDesk: Add `external_author` alias for `service_desk_reply_to`
description:
On the `Issue` model, since `service_desk_reply_to` is used for both cases:

- Which external email addresses are receiving updates to this issue?
- Which email address originally created this issue via Service Desk?

Let's semantically separate these things by renaming the column on `issue` from `service_desk_reply_to` to `external_author`. 

As a first iteration, the email address in `external_author` should receive notifications as if it was `service_desk_reply_to`. Copying of the external author to the external participants will take place as part of #226988.

No feature flag needed since functionality does not externally change.

(note that this issue description has changed so the discussion below is for the original context, which was "add single email participant via quick action")

title: Workhorse bypass allows files in /tmp to be read via Maven Repository APIs
description:
**[HackerOne report #908796](https://hackerone.com/reports/908796)** by `ledz1996` on 2020-06-26, assigned to @ankelly:

### Summary

Similar issue to #848415 and #876998  
As far as we know there exists an `UploadedFile.from_params` leads to a series of Workhorse bypass vulnerability.  
There exists one in maven APIs before but have been patched due to this issue

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/209080

However, the route Detecting in Workhorse sees `%2f` as `/`.  
So this mean  
- If a full path for a project to put in for the API is `000173%2fpackages%2fmaven`, the Workhorse will see this as `000173/packages/maven` and treat this as a valid path for  

***internal/upstream/routes.go***  
```go  
		route("PUT", apiPattern+`v4/projects/[0-9]+/packages/maven/`, upload.BodyUploader(api, signingProxy, preparers.packages)),  
```  
This will proceed us to bypass the Workhorse authorizing in RoR part, thus result in system file/object storage enumerating by using `file.path` or `file.remote_id`.

### Steps to reproduce

1.  Create an Project and Note the ID of the Project. For example: ID 40  
2. Create a subgroup and project with the following path: 0040/packages/maven  
3. Send the PUT request to the following URL: `/api/v4/projects/0040%2fpackages%2fmaven/package/?file.path=../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd` Along with Header: Private-Token: which is the token for accessing the API  
or `/api/v4/projects/0040%2fpackages%2fmaven/package/?file.remote_id=object-id` for Object Storage  
4. If its response with 500 -> the file/ object is not exists,  400 -> The file exists.  
Why 500 code means not exists:  
[fileenum1.PNG](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/63796ab0-f93c-46ef-81ab-611d3435b4c0/fileenum1.PNG)

Uploaded a video for this:   
[bandicam_2020-06-26_17-13-53-860.mp4](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/20e204d0-4378-4b16-9f94-5e5f639dbb17/bandicam_2020-06-26_17-13-53-860.mp4)

#### Results of GitLab environment info

```

System information

Proxy:		no  
Current User:	git  
Using RVM:	no

Git Version:	2.27.0  
Sidekiq Version:5.2.7  
Go Version:	unknown

GitLab information  
Version:	13.1.0-ee  
Revision:	1fa237df2f4  
Directory:	/opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-rails  
DB Adapter:	PostgreSQL  
DB Version:	11.7  
URL:		http://gitlab.example.vm  
HTTP Clone URL:	http://gitlab.example.vm/some-group/some-project.git  
SSH Clone URL:	git@gitlab.example.vm:some-group/some-project.git  
Elasticsearch:	no  
Geo:		no  
Using LDAP:	no  
Using Omniauth:	yes  
Omniauth Providers: saml

GitLab Shell  
Version:	13.3.0  
Repository storage paths:  
- default: 	/var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories  
GitLab Shell path:		/opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-shell  
Git:		/opt/gitlab/embedded/bin/git

```

## Impact

Disclose existence of a file in system, Object Storage, etc.

## Attachments

title: Add Delete buttons to the SSH tab of the credential inventory
description:
### Problem to solve

Currently, the [credential inventory](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36742) provides passive insight to `administrators` and `group owners`. With the introduction of credential management capabilities like [optional SSH key expiration](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36243) and [PAT expiration](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/17344) (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/118893 for gitlab.com), additional functionality is required to enable `administrators` and `group owners` to facilitate the rotation of credentials once they're expired.

GitLab would like to strike a balance between necessary policy definition and enforcement that compliance-minded organizations require and maintaining a great developer experience. Abrupt credential revocation is disruptive and frustrating, but an organization unable to rotate credentials for their users faces an increased risk of a credential's compromise.

There's no way to delete SSH credentials on behalf of `users` for `administrators` and `group owners`, who need to enforce this action.

### Further details

This was split out from #214811 per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214811#note_369945751.

### Intended users

* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)

### Solution

In the "SSH" tab of the [credentials inventory](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36742), add a `Delete` button that appears for each SSH credential.  Clicking this button causes a confirmation modal to appear.  Confirming via the modal causes the SSH credential to be deleted.

![SSH](/uploads/795a7205e0b99b95b3a1f681e6768fbf/SSH.png)

### Implementation breakdown

* Add or modify the path to delete SSH keys for `admin/credentials` & `groups` in the ~backend
* Add an additional column with the `Delete` button

### Follow-up

* Improve the confirmation modal https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235945

The user should understand exactly where the comment pin will be placed and have a minimally obstructed view of the design when hovering.


### Proposal

Use `cursor: crosshair` when hovering on the design rather than a custom icon. All clicking behaviors remain unchanged.

title: SAST Config UI Page - Basic SAST Wide Settings - Implement form control components
description:
This issue tracks the creation of the form control components that are present in the [MVC design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830).

For this iteration, the SAST Configuration UI will only expose text fields for configurable variables.

A [container component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231370) will consume the component created in _this_ issue, and create an instance of it for each occurrence of a [SAST configuration entity](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/app/graphql/types/ci_configuration/sast/entity_type.rb) with type `string` yielded by the GraphQL query for [`sastCiConfiguration`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/doc/api/graphql/reference/gitlab_schema.graphql#L9882-9885) (See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231372).

## Implementation plan

- [x] Add input sizing to GitLab UI
    - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/merge_requests/1604
- [x] Add GlFormText to GitLab UI
    - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/merge_requests/1605
- [ ] Implement form input component
    - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37812
    - Props will likely match fields of the [SAST configuration entity type](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/app/graphql/types/ci_configuration/sast/entity_type.rb), excluding `options`, which isn't relevant for `text`/`string` configuration entities.
    - The `description` field will be rendered via the `label` slot on the existing `GlFormInput` component.
    - Standard `v-model` bindings: `{ prop: 'value', event: 'input' }`.
    - Event payload should be new `value`
    - Parent dynamic form container component would be responsible for feeding this event payload into some larger data structure, suitable for form submission
    - Must have "Restore default" functionality as described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830#design-proposal-configuration-ui-with-dynamic-restore-to-default-link. This can use the `helpText` prop on existing `GlFormInput` component.
    - See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216635#note_371938012 for a discussion about description/help text positioning.

epic.title: SAST Config UI Page - Basic SAST Wide Settings

title: Project Level Access Tokens and TOS
description:
Project-level access tokens should be able to be used without the Bot User having to accept TOS.

When trying to use the project level access token you get the error below:

> GitlabGetError: 403: 403 Forbidden - You (@project_64_bot1) must accept the Terms of Service in order to perform this action. Please access GitLab from a web browser to accept these terms.

I think this can be mitigated by impersonating the bot user and accepting the TOS? Though, I guess this prevents use of bot users without an admin, just how we want it.

## Workaround (requires access to the [GitLab Rails Console](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/troubleshooting/navigating_gitlab_via_rails_console.html))

1. Access the GitLab Rails Console - `sudo gitlab-rails console`
1. Find the Project Access Token bot by username - `user = User.find_by_username(<username>)`
1. Find the TOS - `terms = ApplicationSetting::Term.latest`
1. Accept the TOS - `Users::RespondToTermsService.new(user, terms).execute(accepted: true)`

epic.title: ✅  Project Level Access Tokens

title: Dependency Scanning NuGet [4.9+] support using packages.lock.json behind feature flag or not announced until vulnerability DB has content
description:
NOTE if you are a user who also would like to see this feature, please UPVOTE 👍 it and comment to help it get prioritized (So it’s raised as part of our [sensing mechanisms]( https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/product-management/process/#sensing-mechanism)

### Problem to solve

.NET Core / C# are both in the top 10 languages used at GitLab, GitHub, and has been requested by our potential and current users. We need to expand support for ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" in order to support these languages.

This must work with offline.

Please see: [Engineering research - Decide next language to add to Dependency Scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217024)

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

no change, identical to other supported managers

### Proposal

* Add NuGet as a supported package manager, and scan `packages.lock.json`. This file is generated by NuGet when [lock files are enabled](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#enabling-lock-file).
* Add metrics if needed (if https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229617 finished you may need to, if it is not yet finished make sure https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229617 includes NuGet)
* In parallel, request NuGet vulnerabilities be ingested
* Update user documentation when both scanner is available and security advisories are ingested

### Further details

NuGet lock files `packages.lock.json` can be supported in Gemnasium. Users need to configure their .NET project to [enable lock files](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#enabling-lock-file), and add `packages.lock.json` to their repo. This feature is available [with NuGet 4.9 or above and with Visual Studio 2017 15.9 or above](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#enabling-lock-file).

NuGet uses [Semantic Versioning 2.0.0](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/concepts/package-versioning#semantic-versioning-200), and a Maven-like syntax for [version ranges](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/concepts/package-versioning#version-ranges). All that could be supported in the Gemnasium vrange library since we already have SemVer support and Maven support. We might have to implement a new vrange plugin that combines SemVer versions with Maven version ranges though. We might be able to implement that in Go, in `gemnasium/semver`.

Dependency file support (as opposed to lock file) could later be implemented by running `nuget` to generate the lock file before parsing it. This lock file parsers would be reused.

### Implementation plan

Add advisories to the vulnerability database:
- [x] provide information about new package type https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/gemnasium-db/-/issues/137
- [x] start ingest advisories https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201781

Prepare test project and CI template:

- [x] open a MR that updates the [CI templates](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml) so that the `rules:exists` of the scanning job match the supported dependency file https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37553
- [x] set up a [test project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests) that features the dependency file https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/csharp-nuget-dotnetcore/-/merge_requests/19

Update analyzer https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/87

- [x] declare [package type](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.12.0/scanner/parser/parser.go#L14) as a Go const
- [x] implement lock file [parser](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.12.0/scanner/parser); it's registered with the new package type, and the dependency files it supports
- [x] implement [vrange](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.12.0/vrange) resolver, to match the affected range with the dependency version
- [x] [register](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.12.0/main.go#L232) the version range resolver with the package type
- [x] add a downstream pipeline to the [CI config](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.12.0/.gitlab-ci.yml#L10), to use the test project for QA
- [x] release a new version https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/releases/v2.13.0

Also update the Rails ~frontend:
- [ ] present the `nuget` package type as `C# (NuGet)` in the dependency list https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38892

Merge CI template, update doc, clean up test project:

- [x] submit the changes to the [CI template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml) !37553 
- [x] make the test project use the `master` of the CI template https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/csharp-nuget-dotnetcore/-/merge_requests/20
- [x] add the package manager to the [supported languages and package managers](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/doc/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/index.md#supported-languages-and-package-managers) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37609

As a side task, it would be useful to improve **developer docs**.

- [x] document the steps involved in supporting a new package manager in [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/94
- [-] turn this issue into an issue template, to be added to the [Secure section](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/secure) of the handbook

### Permissions and Security

There should be no changes to ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" permissions.

### Documentation

This should work as documented for the other ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" supported languages and frameworks

Please add this to the [supported languages and frameworks table](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/index.html#supported-languages-and-package-managers), be explicit about versions and lock files

Please add any variables, notes or warnings that are needed for this into the user documentation. For example what type of lock files are expected or looked at and links to places where they can see how they turn on their lock files (external docs)

Please link to the feedback issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227875 to allow people to request other versions.

### Availability & Testing

You must have a test project, and basic tests, specific to making sure NuGet is supported that will run each release to ensure nothing breaks (if a parameter is changed and is not backwards compatible)

This must be incorporated into both online and offline test suites. Work with ~Quality to accomplish, they will setup what to mimic, and you will implement based on the pattern.

The test project should also be documented in the list of test projects quality is maintaining.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Users with NuGet projects get Dependency Scanning reports. They can see the dependencies of their NuGet projects in the Dependency List, and are notified about vulnerabilities affecting these dependencies.

### Links / references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217024

epic.title: Add support of .NET Core or C# or Framework in Dependency Scanning

title: Dependency Scanning Conan support using conan.lock behind feature flag or not announced until vulnerability DB has content
description:
NOTE if you are a user who also would like to see this feature, please UPVOTE 👍 it and comment to help it get prioritized (So it’s raised as part of our [sensing mechanisms]( https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/product-management/process/#sensing-mechanism)

### Problem to solve

C / C++ are both in the top 10 languages used at GitLab, GitHub, and have been requested by our potential and current users. We need to expand support for ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" in order to support these languages.

This must work with offline.

Please see: [Engineering research - Decide next language to add to Dependency Scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217024)

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

no change, identical to other supported managers
</details>

### Proposal

* Add Conan as a supported package manager, and scan `conan.lock`. This file is generated by Conan when running `conan graph lock`.
* Add metrics if needed (if https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229617 finished you may need to, if it is not yet finished make sure https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229617 includes Conan)
* In parallel, request Conan vulnerabilities be ingested
* Update user documentation when both scanner is available and security advisories are ingested

### Further details

Conan lock files `conan.lock` can be supported in Gemnasium. These files are generated when running `conan graph lock`.

Conan uses [node-semver](https://pypi.org/project/node-semver/) (Python package) in its [version ranges](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/conanfile/attributes.html#version-ranges), so [vrange/npm](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/tree/v2.10.1/vrange/npm) could probably be reused to match a Conan version against the affected range of a Conan-related security advisory, without any modification.

Dependency file support (as opposed to lock file) could later be implemented by running `conan graph lock` to generate the lock file before parsing it. This lock file parsers would be reused.

### Implementation plan

Add advisories to the vulnerability database:
- [x] provide information about new package type https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/gemnasium-db/-/issues/139
- [x] start ingest advisories https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229734

Set up a [test project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests)
- [x] create a test project that provides a `conan.lock` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/c-conan/-/merge_requests/3

Update Gemnasium https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/98
- [x] implement lock file [parser](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/tree/master/scanner/parser) in [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium), to parse `conan.lock`
- [x] make sure [vrange/npm](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/tree/master/vrange/npm) can be used for Conan advisories, and enable it for Conan
- [x] add test project to QA, in the CI config

Update Dependency Scanning template https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/39811
- [x] update the `rules:exists` of the `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job to match `conan.lock`, in the [Dependency Scanning CI template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml)
- [x] update https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/c-conan to fetch the CI template from the master branch of `gitlab` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/c-conan/-/merge_requests/6

Update Dependency Scanning docs
- [x] update the list of [supported languages and package managers](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/doc/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/index.md#supported-languages-and-package-managers); See [documentation](#documentation) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40699

Update Rails Frontend
- [x] format Conan package manager in dependency list https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40811

### Permissions and Security

There should be no changes to ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" permissions.

### Documentation

This should work as documented for the other ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" supported languages and frameworks

Please add this to the [supported languages and frameworks table](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/index.html#supported-languages-and-package-managers), be explicit about versions and lock files

Please add any variables, notes or warnings that are needed for this into the user documentation. For example what type of lock files are expected or looked at and links to places where they can see how they turn on their lock files (external docs)

Please link to the feedback issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227875 to allow people to request other versions.

### Availability & Testing

You must have a test project, and basic tests, specific to making sure Conan is supported that will run each release to ensure nothing breaks (if a parameter is changed and is not backwards compatible)

This must be incorporated into both online and offline test suites. Work with ~Quality to accomplish, they will setup what to mimic, and you will implement based on the pattern.

The test project should also be documented in the list of test projects quality is maintaining.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Users with Conan projects get Dependency Scanning reports. They can see the dependencies of their Conan projects in the Dependency List, and are notified about vulnerabilities affecting these dependencies.

### Links / references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217024

title: Add GitLab username and display name to JiraUser GraphQL type
description:
To generate the initial Jira-GitLab user mapping, the frontend calls the GraphQL `jiraImportUsers` mutation and gets back a list of `JiraUser`s with the following fields:

- `gitlabId`
- `jiraAccountID`
- `jiraDisplayName`
- `jiraEmail`

However, with only `gitlabId` we cannot show the user which GitLab username/name this corresponds to (for showing in the form dropdown) unless the frontend makes another API call to get the GitLab username from these `gitlabId`s.

To solve this, we could add `gitlabUsername` and `gitlabName` fields to the `JiraUser` GraphQL type so the frontend can get this information in the same API call as the ID.

title: [Wiki] find page should return nil if not found
description:
Severl errors (such as https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1673927/?referrer=gitlab_plugin) are caused by calls to `find_page` that expect the call to return `nil` if not found. Currently we are raising errors for invalid arguments, but for the most case we should just return not-found here too.

```
GRPC::InvalidArgument: 3:WikiFindPage: revision can't contain ':'
  grpc/generic/active_call.rb:31:in `check_status'
    fail GRPC::BadStatus.new_status_exception(
  grpc/generic/active_call.rb:181:in `attach_status_results_and_complete_call'
    recv_status_batch_result.check_status
  grpc/generic/active_call.rb:170:in `receive_and_check_status'
    attach_status_results_and_complete_call(batch_result)
  grpc/generic/active_call.rb:338:in `each_remote_read_then_finish'
    receive_and_check_status

ArgumentError: 3:WikiFindPage: revision can't contain ':'
  gitlab/git/wraps_gitaly_errors.rb:11:in `rescue in wrapped_gitaly_errors'
    raise ArgumentError.new(e)
  gitlab/git/wraps_gitaly_errors.rb:6:in `wrapped_gitaly_errors'
    def wrapped_gitaly_errors(&block)
  gitlab/git/wiki.rb:101:in `page'
    wrapped_gitaly_errors do
  wiki.rb:118:in `find_page'
    if page = wiki.page(title: page_title, version: version, dir: page_dir)
  wiki_actions.rb:180:in `block in page'
    wiki.find_page(*page_params)
...
(148 additional frame(s) were not displayed)

ArgumentError: 3:WikiFindPage: revision can't contain ':'
```

title: Change the default order for packages in the package registry list view to default to "published" instead of "created"
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Users can often have a variety of packages in a single registry. By default, we currently sort this created date. However, the timestamp may actually be the "published" date. Elsewhere in the Package stage and package registry UI, we focus on the published date. This current setup may cause confusion for users.

| Current UI w/ Created Date Sort |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-06-29_at_14.21.37](/uploads/d61cfec833d642202ac73181220e9909/Screen_Shot_2020-06-29_at_14.21.37.png)|

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Ensure that we're sorting the list of packages by the date users expect.


### Proposal

Switch the default sort to "Published" and change the line copy from "changed" to "published" followed by the date the package was added to the registry.

| Ordered by Published Date |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-06-29_at_14.30.59](/uploads/548f298286f520e371ee5d604700d4f1/Screen_Shot_2020-06-29_at_14.30.59.png)|

### Further details

I'd like to take a moment to confirm that the date we're currently sorting by is in fact a created date and not the published date.

n/a

We may need to update the possible sorting options, as well as any screenshots of the package registry list view.

n/a

The default sorting mechanism used in the Package Registry is clear, accurate, and what users expect.

no

title: Explore adding limit for File Blame page as files with large history will crash the browser
description:
In our efforts to performance test the File Blame feature [we've recently discovered that files with a large showable history will actually cause severe instability to the browser, sometimes even crashing it](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/performance-sitespeed/-/merge_requests/1#note_369132319).

Some examples of files that cause this:
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blame/master/fixtures/emojis/index.json
* https://gitlab.com/ddevault/linux/-/blame/master/MAINTAINERS
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blame/master/data/team.yml

Notably this is a pain point for most Git products, with [no other products being able to handle the same](https://forgeperf.org/#repo-blame-worst-case).

Much like we do for rendering large files where we don't show them if they're over 1mb in size we should look to add a similar limit or pagination for File Blame to prevent this bad experience from happening to users as well as reduce strain on our servers.

title: Review global search code regexes in Elasticsearch for accuracy
description:
This popped up as part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2318.

Upon reviewing the existing set of regexes ([source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/lib/elastic/latest/config.rb#L58)), one of them seemed odd.

### capture terms inside quotes, removing the quotes

This is the existing regex:

`'"((?:\\"|[^"]|\\")*)"'`

The duplicate literal match on `\"` seems off. This can probably be simplified to:

`'"((?:\\"|[^"])*)"'`

And the same applies to the regex following that one, for single quotes.

cc @DylanGriffith @dgruzd

epic.title: Elasticsearch analyzer doesn't account for all code cases

title: N+1s in PipelineDetailsEntity when serializing multiple TriggeredPipelineEntity
description:
## Problem

from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35232#note_368325716

>>>
We don't preload properly the `triggered_pipelines` and `triggered_by_pipelines`. The `97` number is what comes up today prior to introducing the `source_job`. In the existing spec examples where we check the number of queries we use a simple pipeline. When serializing a pipeline with upstream or (worse) downstream pipelines we introduce N+1s.

From inspecting the recorded log it seems that the majority of the queries are related to routing when building the project urls but there is also other data not being preloaded properly. Things can be worse if we use the `expanded` version of the serializer, where for each downstream pipeline we fetch their own upstream/downstream pipelines.
>>>

## Solution

- preload properly data used to serialize [`triggered_by_pipeline` and `triggered_pipelines`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/c6ff21196da73236e646f7c511bd69ed8cd5d3b8/app/serializers/pipeline_serializer.rb#L64-65).
- ensure that with [`expanded` serializer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/c6ff21196da73236e646f7c511bd69ed8cd5d3b8/app/serializers/triggered_pipeline_entity.rb#L32-38) we can still reduce the number of queries being fired.

title: Remove possible duplicates from the usage data
description:
As @patrickbajao suggested in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35224#note_369625787, We have these definitions under `ee/lib/ee/gitlab/usage_data.rb`. 

```ruby
def system_usage_data
  super.tap do |usage_data
    usage_data[:counts].merge!
      {
         ...
         projects_enforcing_code_owner_approval: count(::Project.without_deleted.non_archived.requiring_code_owner_approval),
         merge_requests_with_optional_codeowners: distinct_count(::ApprovalMergeRequestRule.code_owner_approval_optional, :merge_request_id),
         merge_requests_with_required_codeowners: distinct_count(::ApprovalMergeRequestRule.code_owner_approval_required, :merge_request_id),
         ...
      }
end
```

```ruby
def usage_activity_by_stage_create(time_perioda)
  super.merge({
    ...
    projects_enforcing_code_owner_approval: distinct_count(::Project.requiring_code_owner_approval.where(time_period), :creator_id),
    merge_requests_with_optional_codeowners: distinct_count(::ApprovalMergeRequestRule.code_owner_approval_optional.where(time_period), :merge_request_id),
    merge_requests_with_required_codeowners: distinct_count(::ApprovalMergeRequestRule.code_owner_approval_required.where(time_period), :merge_request_id),
    ...
  })
end
```
They seem like duplications which can be removed, but I wonder if they serve different purposes? Can we use the ones from `usage_activity_by_stage_create` and remove the ones from `system_usage_data`? 
Interestingly, `projects_enforcing_code_owner_approval` seem to be defined slight differently as well besides the additional `time_period` query. 

Would you be able to check how we are using this currently and confirm if we can clean them up? @danielgruesso

title: Shared group not visible
description:
There are scenarios when a shared group is not visible in the group hierarchy in My Groups and the Group Overview page. The group is still accessible by entering the URL directly.

**Steps to Recreate**
1. Create a group A with 2 subgroups (B, C).
1. Add a subgroup to each of those subgroups(B->D, C->E).
1. Add a user to one of the child subgroups (D).
1. Share that subgroup (D) with the child subgroup (E).

**Expected Results**

User can see groups A, B, C, D and E in a hierarchy in My Groups and the Group overview page. User should also see the projects from each group (including the projects from the shared subgroup) in My Projects and the Group overview page.

**Actual Result**

User can only see group A, B, D.

**Example**

This is what the full group structure looks like
![Screen_Shot_2020-06-26_at_10.05.08_PM](/uploads/a4f49388b04bb6b609d4fdd1404d8c1f/Screen_Shot_2020-06-26_at_10.05.08_PM.png)

title: Instrument self-managed data for Manage:Import PI
description:
Identify what data is needed and instrument getting the data from self-managed instances for the [Importers Performance Indicator](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/analytics/-/issues/4244) (fka. the North Star Metric): **Percentage of new projects that are imported**

## Proposal

- Determine whether new import project metrics are added to usage ping
- If not, add new import project metrics to usage ping

## Technical Implementation

We already have total number of projects here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L133

And projects imported from GitHub: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L134

My (@dennis) suggestion would be to add an additional usage metric, e.g., `projects_imported: count(Project.where.not(import_type: nil))`.

From that point we can create a Sisense dashboard to compare `projects_imported` against total `projects`.

## Definition of done

- We are able to query data in Sisense on our usage ping data containing information about new import metric.

title: Notify group owners as they approach the user limit in their subscription
description:
### Problem

GitLab.com group owners do not get any alerts when they are approaching their user limit. This can cause surprises for customers at renewal, and when they are contacted or charged for overages.

### Proposal

We should provide alerting to the owners via an in-app banner:


1. Banner displayed to members of the parent namespace which have `owner` permissions
1. Banner displayed on all pages with the parent namespace, nested subgroups and projects
1. Where possible we should mimic the experience created in: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217804
1. Banner should be displayed according to this threshold: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217804#note_346508547
1. We should be comparing the `Seats currently in use` to the `Seats in subscription` counts for this threshold
1. Allow users to dismiss the banner
1. Show the banner again after dismissal when the threshold is triggered again by additional users being added.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

- Ensure tests are added that check if this banner **only** shows when the threshold is reached and not before.
- Frontend tests
  - Validate that banner appears appropriately with close button and content.
  - Validate that when closing the banner, the banner **does** close.
- Are we toggling something in the backend for ~UX that **doesn't** show the banner if it's already been displayed?  (Something like a "Don't show again." flag)

title: Remove remaining "instance statistics" code
description:
### Problem to solve

Once we have finished moving features like [Cohorts](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/205909) and [DevOps Score](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/224716) out of "instance statistics", there will be no more use for it.

### Further details

"Instance statistics" is also called "Analytics Workspace" and "centralized analytics".

### Proposal

Remove all of these:
* Analytics link in the top navbar and left navbar
* Instance-level analytics route(s) like `/-/analytics` (per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/224146)
* Any remaining instance-level Analytics code (nav, helpers, etc)
* References in the documentation to "instance statistics", "Analytics Workspace", "centralized analytics"

## Screenshots

Here is what Instance-level Analytics area looks like. These 2 features would be moved, and the navbar link and left-nav would be eliminated:
![Screen_Shot_2020-03-25_at_12.55.06_PM](/uploads/b4f4417d65dd7f87f05ccaad709a50a8/Screen_Shot_2020-03-25_at_12.55.06_PM.png)

title: Move DevOps Score out of instance statistics
description:
## Overview

With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196455 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196454, we can start hiding Instance Statistics in the top navbar when this feature's admin-only. 

We're not confident that Instance Statistics, as currently displayed in the navbar, is the right place for these features to thrive. We should consider moving them elsewhere or refactor the Instance Statistics area into a more useful tool.

## Proposal

* Move DevOps Score to the admin Analytics area (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233833).
* Update the documentation for how to navigate to DevOps Score.

title: Introduce EULA acceptance at license upload for Self-Managed instances
description:
## Summary

In a decision made [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/issues/1360#note_368446506) we will no longer require a manual EULA process. Instead, we will make the EULA acceptance for self-managed customers as part of the license upload process.

Reference

* Legal approval: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/issues/1574#note_368965216
* Approved language:

>Unless otherwise agreed to in writing with GitLab, by clicking "Upload License" you agree that your use of GitLab Software is subject to the Subscription Agreement, updated from time to time, at https://about.gitlab.com/Subscription-Agreement.

### Requirements

* Introduce checkbox and text according to designs
* Do not allow upload of license unless the checkbox is selected

### Testing & Availability
1. User navigate to `License` section with checkbox unselected by default
2. Link text redirects page to current Subscription Term
3. Upload License button is disabled when checkbox is unselected
4. User can successfully upload a license file when checkbox is selected

epic.title: Migrate EULA acceptance to in-app process

title: Group Setting: Add toggle to remove Analytics left nav item
description:
### Problem to solve

In a group, no left sidebar menus can be turned off, but they can for projects. However, there are a number of use cases where a GitLab group may be used and the GitLab features in the sidebar aren't relevant.

### Proposal

- Group-level "General" settings should have an expandable section for "Group features", with the explanation "Enable/disable group features."  This should be the first section, above "Permissions, LFS, 2FA".
- Inside the "Group features" section, there should be a toggle for "Analytics".
  - Explanation text should say: "Insights about contributors, repositories, etc."
  - Help tip should say: "Learn more about group-level analytics features in our [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/analytics/#group-level-analytics)."
  - Toggle should default to enabled.
  - After a change has been saved, an alert message should be displayed ([example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/a23e63096926950a415740d4e473445d/Screen_Shot_2020-11-13_at_2.21.14_PM.png)).
- The "Analytics" menu item should only be displayed in the group-level left-nav if the toggle is enabled.

![Screen_Shot_2020-11-13_at_2.15.21_PM](/uploads/70e1a61d052187f712c91fc877b7ac23/Screen_Shot_2020-11-13_at_2.15.21_PM.png)

### Documentation

We will need to update our [documentation on group settings](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#group-settings).

### Availability and Testing

Adequate test coverage required, preferably lower level tests. Please include a SET in MR review and run `package-and-qa` manual job for regression purposes.

title: Move Members to Project Information in the left nav
description:
### Problem to solve

The left side navigation contains quick links essential to navigating between project features. Some items in the left sidebar can be disabled and hidden from the menu (like Wiki, Snippets, Requirements, etc), reducing the visual clutter in the list. However, some items, like `Members` are inherent to the concept of a project and it doesn't make sense to let someone remove it as a menu item. 

However, the feedback remains that the left sidebar can be overwhelming and difficult to distinguish from one another. 

## 🔬 Research
Conducted a number of research studies to better understand user perception of this change:
- [Dovetail research link](https://dovetailapp.com/projects/c2337347-089c-46a1-be4e-0d1a37ca8fdc/readme)

As of 2021-05-06 the data points overwhelmingly to `Overview` as the logical location.

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-06_at_1.59.47_PM](/uploads/a3b451b3338f795c0dfb5a89a3bf0c64/Screen_Shot_2021-05-06_at_1.59.47_PM.png)

### Proposal

We should reconsider the placement of `Members` on the project and group level. We don't want to negatively impact usability, so it should remain accessible and discoverable. 

#### Visuals
| Groups-live | Groups-updated | Projects-live | Projects-updated |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![Groups-Original](/uploads/b5804ca398bccae07b05d1ee64da4d35/Groups-Original.png) | ![Groups-updated](/uploads/9352450e8744b96e06dfbba556e43b1b/Groups-updated.png) | ![Projects-original](/uploads/aacf98a75511b5f0c7c8a31a388433d0/Projects-original.png) | ![Projects-updated](/uploads/2f74dd9fdbf3bf8146277ef73de356db/Projects-updated.png) |


### Documentation

We will need to update our documentation on project settings.

title: Project Setting: Add toggle to remove Security & Compliance left nav item (FE)
description:
## Why are we doing this work

In project settings, there are a number of left sidebar menu items that can be toggled off such as the repository, issues, and snippets; however, there are a number of items that cannot be toggled off which leads to a poor user experience if the project isn't ever going to utilize those features.

We should allow users to toggle off the Security & Compliance left nav item in Project Settings => General => Visibility, Project Features, and Permissions.

This issue represents the ~frontend work required to deliver this feature. The ~backend work is tracked in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/290112. 

## Relevant links

-->

<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.

The file contains many examples on how to create a toggle. Follow the same conventions. We'll need to collaborate with the ~backend here because we still need a setting name which they'll provide. As an example, you can check `app/views/layouts/nav/sidebar/_project.html.haml:82`. I believe that displays the issue tab only if it's enabled. We'll probably need to do something similar.
